q: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) assigns permissions to:
options: Individual users based on their specific daily tasks
Roles, which are then assigned to users
Data objects based on their security classification level
Network segments to restrict physical access
Active Directory groups based on geographic location
expl: RBAC scales by managing permissions on Roles, reducing administrative overhead.

q: What does 'Non-Repudiation' guarantee?
options: Data cannot be altered in transit between two systems
The sender cannot deny having sent the message or performed the action
The system will remain available even during a denial-of-service attack
A user's identity is completely anonymized in the audit logs
Data backups cannot be corrupted by ransomware
expl: Proof of origin/delivery preventing denial of action.

q: A 'Firewall' is an example of which type of security control?
options: Administrative Control
Physical Control
Technical / Logical Control
Detective Control
Compensating Control
expl: Firewalls are software/hardware devices implementing technical rules (Logical).

q: Which regulation impacts the handling of US Healthcare data (PHI)?
options: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS)
Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
expl: HIPAA = US Healthcare. SOX = Finance. PCI = Credit Cards.

q: What is 'Phishing'?
options: Exploiting a vulnerability in a web application's input fields
A social engineering attack via electronic communication to steal credentials
Intercepting unencrypted data packets over a public Wi-Fi network
Using automated tools to guess passwords via brute force
Gaining unauthorized physical access by tailgating an employee
expl: Phishing is a social engineering attack focusing on human deception.

q: Tokenization replaces sensitive data with:
options: A mathematically irreversible hash value
Non-sensitive surrogates (tokens) that map back to the original via a secure vault
Ciphertext generated using a public key infrastructure (PKI)
Masked characters (e.g., replacing the first 12 digits of a credit card with 'X')
Synthetic data generated by a machine learning algorithm
expl: Tokens allow systems to process data without exposing real values, reversible only by the token vault.

q: Which is a 'Physical' security control?
options: A mandatory password rotation policy
An Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
A biometric scanner at the entrance to a server room
A Virtual Private Network (VPN) requirement for remote workers
An Access Control List (ACL) on a network router
expl: Tangible barriers preventing physical access.

q: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) requires factors from at least how many categories?
options: One category, provided it is a biometric factor
Two or more distinct categories (e.g., knowledge, possession, inherence)
Three distinct categories, including a physical hardware token
Two factors from the same category (e.g., two different passwords)
It depends entirely on the data classification level
expl: Two or more (e.g., Something you know + Something you have).

q: What is the purpose of a 'Demilitarized Zone' (DMZ) in network security?
options: To physically isolate database servers in a separate, locked room
To expose public-facing services to an untrusted network while isolating the internal network
To encrypt all data at rest before it is moved to cloud storage
To serve as a honeypot to attract and trap malicious hackers
To bypass firewall rules for executive-level employees
expl: DMZ creates a buffer zone between the public internet and the private trusted network.

q: Which of the following is the BEST example of Reference Data?
options: A specific customer profile (e.g., John Doe)
A unique product identifier (e.g., SKU 12345)
A standardized list of ISO Country Codes (e.g., US, DE, FR)
A daily sales transaction record
A monthly aggregated financial report
expl: Reference data defines the set of permissible values (codes, lookups).

q: What is the primary goal of Entity Resolution (Match and Merge)?
options: To standardize the format of addresses across all systems
To identify if multiple records across systems refer to the same real-world object
To enforce referential integrity between fact and dimension tables
To automatically correct spelling errors in customer names
To generate a unique surrogate key for every new transaction
expl: Identifying duplicates across disparate sources to create a single view.

q: In MDM, what characterizes a 'Registry' style architecture?
options: The hub stores a complete, consolidated 'Golden Record' with all attributes
The hub stores only identifiers and cross-references, leaving the actual data in source systems
Master data is authored directly in the hub and pushed to downstream systems
The hub acts as a real-time transactional database for all enterprise applications
Data is synchronized bidirectionally between the hub and all source systems in real-time
expl: Registry holds pointers/IDs and cross-references, but data remains in source systems.

q: Which MDM style allows authoring of master data directly in the central hub, making it the System of Record?
options: Registry Style
Consolidated Style
Transaction / Centralized Style
Coexistence Style
Federated Style
expl: Transaction/Centralized hub implies the hub is the authoritative source for creation/edits.

q: What are 'Survivorship' rules used for in MDM?
options: To determine the data retention period before archival
To determine the 'winning' value for an attribute when merging conflicting records
To establish which source system is allowed to create new master records
To define the failover process for the MDM hub during a disaster
To calculate the confidence score during probabilistic matching
expl: Survivorship logic creates the Golden Record by picking the best values from sources.

q: Master Data typically describes:
options: The events and actions of the business (e.g., Sales, Deliveries)
The core entities of the business (e.g., Customers, Products, Locations)
The descriptive context of the data (e.g., Data Types, Lineage)
The aggregated performance metrics (e.g., Quarterly Revenue)
The allowable values for a specific field (e.g., Status Codes)
expl: Master data represents the core entities (Nouns) involved in transactions.

q: Taxonomies and Ontologies are tools primarily used in managing:
options: High-velocity streaming data
Reference Data, Vocabularies, and Knowledge Graphs
Physical database schemas and DDL scripts
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) policies
Data warehouse ETL transformation logic
expl: They structure classification and meaning, core to Reference Data.

q: Probabilistic Matching uses what mechanism to identify duplicates?
options: Deterministic rules based on exact string equality (e.g., SSN = SSN)
Statistical algorithms and scoring weights to determine the likelihood of a match
Manual review by Data Stewards for every potential duplicate
Referential integrity constraints enforced by the database engine
Standardization routines that format all data identically before comparison
expl: Fuzzy logic/scores determine the likelihood of a match.

q: Which of the following is NOT a common Master Data domain?
options: Customer / Party
Product / Service
Location / Geography
Financial Account
Point-of-Sale Transaction
expl: Logs are event/transaction data, not master entities.

q: Who is responsible for defining valid values and business definitions for Reference Data sets?
options: Enterprise Data Architects
Business Data Stewards
Database Administrators (DBAs)
The Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The Master Data Management (MDM) software vendor
expl: Stewards manage the content and business rules for data.

q: OLAP stands for:
options: Online Analytical Processing
Online Transaction Processing
Operational Logical Application Processing
Optimized Linear Analytics Protocol
Object-Level Access Protocol
expl: OLAP is for analysis. OLTP is for transactions.

q: Bill Inmon's definition of a Data Warehouse includes all of the following characteristics EXCEPT:
options: Subject-Oriented
Integrated
Time-Variant
Non-Volatile
Volatile (Continuously updated in real-time)
expl: Inmon defines DW as Non-Volatile. 'Volatile' is incorrect.

q: What is 'Slicing and Dicing'?
options: Partitioning a large fact table horizontally to improve query performance
Navigating a multi-dimensional OLAP cube by filtering and grouping dimensions
Removing personally identifiable information (PII) from a dataset
Extracting data from a source system and loading it into a staging area
Normalizing a denormalized table into Third Normal Form (3NF)
expl: Standard interaction with multi-dimensional data (OLAP).

q: Which schema typically involves normalizing dimensions into multiple related tables?
options: Star Schema
Snowflake Schema
Fact Constellation Schema
Data Vault Schema
Third Normal Form (3NF) Schema
expl: Snowflake normalizes dimensions to remove redundancy, unlike Star.

q: A Data Mart is best described as:
options: The centralized, integrated repository for all enterprise historical data
A subset of a data warehouse focused on a specific subject area or department
A staging area used exclusively for data cleansing and transformation
A real-time operational data store (ODS) used for transaction processing
A data lake designed to store raw, unstructured data
expl: Marts are subject-oriented subsets (e.g., Marketing Mart).

q: CDC stands for:
options: Centralized Data Catalog
Change Data Capture
Continuous Data Cleansing
Customer Data Consolidation
Critical Data Classification
expl: CDC identifies and captures changes in source systems for ETL.

q: What is the 'Staging Area' in a DW architecture?
options: The semantic layer where business users access finalized reports
A temporary storage area where raw data lands before transformation and loading
The permanent archive for historical data that is rarely accessed
The operational system where transactions are initially recorded
The dimensional model containing the fact and dimension tables
expl: Buffer zone for extraction and preliminary cleaning.

q: R-OLAP refers to:
options: Relational OLAP (querying data directly from relational tables)
Real-time OLAP (processing data streams in memory)
Remote OLAP (accessing cubes hosted in a cloud environment)
Robust OLAP (providing high availability and disaster recovery)
Multidimensional OLAP (storing data in proprietary cube structures)
expl: ROLAP leaves data in relational tables; MOLAP uses cubes.

q: Kimball's Data Warehouse methodology is often described as:
options: Top-Down (building the Enterprise Data Warehouse first)
Bottom-Up (building dimensional Data Marts connected by a bus architecture)
Data Vault (using hubs, links, and satellites)
Data Mesh (decentralized, domain-oriented data products)
Schema-on-Read (storing raw data in a Data Lake)
expl: Kimball = Bottom-Up (Bus Matrix). Inmon = Top-Down (CIF).

q: Ungoverned Self-Service BI primarily risks creating:
options: Data silos, inconsistent business definitions, and 'Spreadmarts'
Overly restrictive data security policies that hinder access
A bottleneck in the IT department due to report requests
An overly complex Enterprise Data Warehouse architecture
Excessive documentation and metadata management overhead
expl: Without governance, users create conflicting definitions and reports.

q: Which is an example of 'Business Metadata'?
options: The physical data type of a column (e.g., VARCHAR(50))
The mapping rules used in an ETL process
The agreed-upon definition and calculation for 'Active Customer'
The execution logs and row counts from the nightly batch job
The index structures applied to a relational database table
expl: Context/Definition for business users. Others are Technical/Operational.

q: Which is an example of 'Technical Metadata'?
options: The name of the Data Owner accountable for a dataset
The business policy governing data retention
The physical database schema, column lengths, and data types
The glossary definition of a specific business term
The data quality score displayed on an executive dashboard
expl: Physical structure details used by developers/DBAs.

q: Data Lineage describes:
options: The hierarchical relationship between a parent entity and its child entities
The path data takes from origin to destination, including all transformations
The historical record of which users accessed a specific data element
The statistical distribution and profiling results of a dataset
The organizational reporting structure of the Data Governance team
expl: Flow/Transformation history (Where did it come from?).

q: A Business Glossary is primarily used to:
options: Document the physical table structures and foreign key relationships
Align business terminology, definitions, and concepts across the enterprise
Store the technical mapping rules for the ETL processes
Manage the access control lists (ACLs) for the data warehouse
Track the operational execution logs of data integration jobs
expl: Shared vocabulary to prevent semantic confusion.

q: Operational Metadata includes:
options: The business definitions of key performance indicators (KPIs)
Execution logs, processing times, error rates, and row counts
The logical data models and entity-relationship diagrams
The data stewardship assignments and RACI matrices
The physical data types and constraints of database columns
expl: Run-time stats generated during processing.

q: What is a 'Metadata Repository'?
options: A staging area used to temporarily hold data before it enters the data warehouse
A centralized database or system specifically designed to store and manage metadata
A document management system used to store PDF versions of data policies
A physical server rack dedicated to hosting the Master Data Management hub
A data lake zone reserved for unstructured log files
expl: The system of record for metadata.
